div1.p: Derivaux recommends utilizing Dr. Taylor for malaria prevention.

div1.head: Letter from R. C. Derivaux to Henry Rose Carter, December 16, 1917
div1.opener:
Personal and Confidential.
OFFICE OF
MALARIAL INVESTIGATIONS
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
U.S. MARINE HOSPITAL
NEW ORLEANS. LA.
December 26, 1917.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
During my last visit to Hamburg, Arkansas,
I again discussed with Dr. Taylor the possibility of utilization
of his services in cantonment work with reference to malaria
prevention, and have since had a letter from him, expresing reiterating his
desire to make whatever training he may have had available to
the Country. I wonder whether you have have had occasion to take
up xxxx the question with Mr. Rose; Taylor plans to enter upon
his new program on February 1, 1918, and while the work he expects
to undertake should have a far-reaching influence on sanitation
in general and in the ultimate, I believe it might be not inadvisable
to consider utilization of his services in a capacity more intimate-
ly connected with the national defence. He feels, naturally, that
a clear understanding should be reached vis-a-vis the Board, and
that ample allowance in time should be made that the several towns negotiated
with xxxx for the new work be informed, as soon as practicable, should a change in plan
result. Our margin of time is small as there is the present work
(Hamburg) to terminate, and the new begun (in a preparatory way)
before February 1. My personal recommendation is in favor of taking
the matter under advisement, possibly for discussion.
